results.notes:
A single fruitbody growing in short grass/moss in the vicinity of mature oaks and other hardwoods. The stipe was deeply inserted (>2") into the ground, and its total recovery was not possible due to the fragile nature of the waterlogged tissue in the area of the volval sack (the soil was very wet). I looked hard for the broken off stipe base but couldn’t find it. This collection bears semblance to obs 421190, which was found in the same general area, so these could be the same species/organism. This theory will be investigated by DNA sequencing.
Cap footprint = 5.5 cm; the flesh = 5 mm thick above stipe; striations = 0.25-0.37R
Gills = 3.5 mm wide max
Stipe = at least 13 cm long and the subterranean portion = 5 cm long (I nicked the stipe surface at the ground level with my knife), 7.5 mm wide at the flaring apex, 6.5 mm at its narrowest point just below the apex, gradually expanding to 9 mm in the lower half but narrowing to 8 mm near the point of break
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 3-Jun-21):
> This collection was sampled for nrITS by Dr. Linas V. Kudzma. Unfortunately, the proposed barcode gene in this organism suffers from extensive heterogeneity. The forward read gave the first 29 characters of nrITS/ITS1 before becoming totally non-specific for the rest of the PCR amplicon: TTGAATTGGAAACCCATGGCTAGTTAGTG. The reverse read gave the last 79 characters of the ITS2 sublocus before becoming totally non-specific for the rest of the trace: ATATTGGCTTGAAAAGACAATCGGTGTGATAATCCTCTATGCACCTTGCAAAGTCTTTCAGCCCCTTTTTTATGATTCA. This was followed by a short LSU fragment starting with “TCT” that is the hallmark of series Penetratrices.
> A BLASTn-100 of the ITS1 fragment returned a total of only 10 hits, of which 7 are accessions of A. justicei (all having 97.3% similarity to the query) and 2 are accession of A. scutum (100% similar to the query), all by Rod Tulloss (RET). A BLASTn-100 of the ITS2 fragment gave a hit list consisting of the following relevant accessions: 5 records of A. penetrans (98.8-100% similarity), 5 records of A. justicei (89.9-100% similarity), and 2 records of A. scutum (100% match), all by RET.
> A. justicei and A. scutum often give complete or mostly complete ITS sequences, though extensive heterogeneity can be a problem at times (see obs 421190 for more details). However, according to RET, not a single sequenced voucher of A. penetrans gave long ITS sequence fragments, let alone full-length sequences (see discussion in the tech tab at http://amanitaceae.org/?Amanita%20penetrans). In fact, only short ITS2 fragments attached to longer LSU fragments have been published by RET in GenBank (i.e., no ITS1-5.8S data at all). It appears that this consistent reluctance of A. penetrans to give up its barcode gene sequence could be a reliable trait to separate it from the sister taxa justicei and scutum. That said, A. penetrans could be a better ID proposal for the present observation. This was exactly the same conclusion I made for obs 374001 (collected many miles away from MO427938) that showed an analogous ITS profile, e.g., the exact location of the two points of heterogeneity, and the overall composition of the contiguous complex heteromorphy. It’s also interesting that A. justicei of obs 421190 – identified by its complete, yet problematic, ITS sequence – was growing no more than 30 yards away from this collection.

results.notes:
A single robust fruitbody growing in short grass/moss in the vicinity of mature oaks and other hardwoods. The stipe was inserted into the ground by at least 6 cm, and its total recovery was not possible due to the fragile nature of the waterlogged tissue in the area of the volval sack (the soil was very wet). I looked hard for the broken off stipe base and volva but couldnâ€™t find them.
This collection was found 15-20 yards away from obs 427938, so first I thought they were the same. However, a more careful comparison suggested they were not (see photos of the two caps side by side). This was further supported by the difference in the color of dried gills, which was pale pinkish-orange in this collection, and, eventually, by the derived nrITS sequences.
- Cap footprint = 7 × 6.3 cm; flesh = 6 mm thick above stipe; striations = 1-1.3 cm long (0.29-0.37R / 0.33-0.43R)
- Gills = 5-6 mm wide
- Stipe = at least 16 cm long overall, with the subterranean portion of 6 cm long (I nicked the stipe surface at the ground level with my knife); 1.1 cm wide at the flaring apex, 9 mm at its narrowest point just below the apex, gradually widening to 1.4 cm in the middle and 1.6 cm near the broken off base
DNA Sequencing Results and Discussion (posted 23-May-21; updated on 24-Jan-23):
Dr. Kudzma sampled this collection for ITS. The forward read delivers a full-length ITS1-5.8S region and the first 34 characters of ITS2 for a total length of 384 base pairs (bps). The read then becomes hopelessly heterogeneous. The reverse read gives the last 88 characters of ITS2 before becoming hopelessly non-specific, too. Thus, there are two points of heterogeneity in ITS2, and that’s why the two reads cannot be joined together for a contiguous full-length ITS sequence. The length of the unresolved region in MO427979 turns out to be 44 bps long, as full-length accessions of this species can be found in GenBank.
Both ITS fragments are a 100% match to 6 accessions of Amanita homolalittenii and 1 accession of Amanita ‘sp-MO04’. The latter entity is known from two collections: from Missouri, obs 209351, and from North Carolina, obs 335735. The difference between the ITS sequences of these two taxa lies in the lengths of a poly-AC repeat in ITS1 and a poly-G repeat in ITS2.
RET still thinks the two species are not conspecific because they look different. The same can be said of Steve Russell’s ‘sp-IN16’ whose sequences mix in with those of RET’s two species. Sampling of single-copy loci could be useful in solving this little puzzle.

results.notes:
Three fruitbodies growing in short grass/moss in the vicinity of oaks and a spruce. From a distance these looked like T. badiceps. I was fooled into thinking so because I had collected that taxon in the same area (~10-15 yards away) two years ago (obs 328651).
To my knowledge, other than T. tabacinus, T. rubrobrunneus is the only other Tylopilus that doesn’t have white pores when young.
The taste of the dried collection was bitter (I am pretty sure I tried it before drying, too, but didn’t record here).

results.notes:
Growing out of moss in sandy soil at the top of a steep stream bank. Very near two beech trees with poplar, white oak, box elder, and pawpaw trees present and fairly close. Area possibly flooded recently.
The mushroom looked old and possibly rotting, which is why I picked and cut it in half. The inside did not seem rotting and smelled of very deep portobello.
Ammonia had no reaction.
Flesh did not seem to bruise orange (as bolete filter says) but it is difficult to tell with the dark flesh.
Dark cap, dark stipe with lighter color near bottom. Blacks/greys/purples. Possible netting texture at top of stipe. Dark pores. Uneven cap surface- not smooth.
No spore print when left overnight. May be too old or possibly recently flooded?

results.notes:
A white sect. Vaginatae, a rare sight at these latitudes. I found it shortly after my arrival to the site as a very young fruitbody with a conical cap and decided to pick at the very end of my foray. When I came back to harvest it almost 3 hours later, it managed to grow taller and expand its cap. The cap is white with just a smattering of cream color on the disc. The only other unusual features are somewhat thick gills/gill edges, sparse short gills and the deeply buried stipe (50% of length subterranean).
Cap: oval-shaped, with a 6.8 × 5.9 cm footprint; flesh 5 mm thick above stipe
Gills: 4-5 mm wide
Stipe: 11 cm long, 1.2 cm wide in the middle, widening a bit more inside the volva sack
Volva: 6 cm tall from bottom of the base to the tip of the longest limb, 1.5 cm wide (volva + stipe), appeared to have been completely subterranean judging from the dirt covering the longest limb
DNA Sequencing Results & Discussion (posted 6-Jun-21):
This collection was sampled for nrITS by Dr. Kudzma.
Unfortunately, the “barcode gene” is a mess in this organism due to lack of homogeneity in the rnDNA repeat. First of all, full-length sequence is not possible because of a complex heterogeneity pattern at the 3’ end of ITS2 sublocus. For this reason, the forward and reverse read cannot be joined together. Also, the long forward read is interspersed with regions “on-and-off” heterogeneity, some of which I was able to resolve, and peppered with isolated single-base ambiguities.
During this work, I became aware that I had recently seen this sequence. Indeed, a quick comparison with the ITS sequence of Amanita justicei of obs 421190 processed just a few days ago confirmed my suspicion. Alignment of the two sequences is shown in Fig. 1. Incidentally, MO421190 was found ~150 yards away from the present observation. While this “albino” collection is likely A. justicei, I don’t think the two vouchers represent the same organism. However, their respective mycelium mats could be interacting through a forest continuum and hybridizing. Hybridization thorough a direct interaction of hyphae or through spore dispersal of the otherwise separate populations might explain the observed similarities and differences in the chromatogram traces.
Dr. Kudzma obtained LSU and RPB-2 sequences on his own but has not shared those data with me yet.

results.notes:
Growing singly in hardwood duff adjacent to a well-rotted hardwood log among hardwood leaf litter. Cap centrally depressed. Basal mycelium white and white rhizomorphs attached to stem base. Clamps absent in all tissue examined. Pileipellis lacking globose or inflated elements. Pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia abundant and present as pseudocystidia, containing brown-pigemented granules in Melzer’s reagent. Basidia measurements: (18.2) 19.8 – 26.1 (27) Ã— (5.4) 5.6 – 6.8 (7) Âµm, Q = (3) 3.1 – 4.75 (4.8); N = 12, Me = 23 Ã— 6 Âµm; Qe = 3.8. Spores warted and appearing angular in polar view. results.notes:
3 fruiting bodies growing caespitose on a small hardwood chunk among leaf litter in a mixed hardwood forest. Caps scaly. Young gills pale gray. Basal mycelium white and cottony. Lamellar structures and pileipellis did not change color significantly in 1M KOH. Caulocystidia smooth, thin-walled, hyaline and clavate. Pileipellis a trichoderm, with terminal elements containing brown intracellular pigment. Terminal element measurements: (30.8) 40.9 – 83.9 (117.8) Ã— (8.4) 9.9 – 15.8 (19.2) Âµm, Q = (3) 3.6 – 7.1 (7.3); N = 30, Me = 62.3 Ã— 13.1 Âµm; Qe = 4.8. Clamps present in the pileipellis. Lamellar trama yellowish-brown in 1M KOH. Pleurocystidia and cheilocystidia absent. Basidia 4-sterigmate. Basidia measurements: (24.7) 25.7 – 34.9 (35.5) Ã— (8.1) 8.8 – 10.4 (11.4) Âµm, Q = (2.4) 2.7 – 3.7 (3.9); N = 10, Me = 30.5 Ã— 9.5 Âµm; Qe = 3.3. Spores angular with 6-7 angles and pink in mass. Spore measurements: (7.4) 7.8 – 8.9 (9.3) Ã— (5.3) 5.5 – 6.17 (6.2) Âµm, Q = (1.3) 1.4 – 1.5 (1.6); N = 30, Me = 8.4 Ã— 5.9 Âµm; Qe = 1.4. Average spore L-D = 2.5.

results.notes:
Growing in leaf litter under mostly oak and hickory trees. In a dense mixed forest in Gordon County, Georgia, US. September 2, 2020.

Cap/upper surface: Medium pink/brown with white flesh. DNS.

Taste: Mild.

Odor: Somewhat of a rancid smell, especially near the cap.

Chemistry: KOH â€“ Red-orange on pores, peach on cap. Ammoniaâ€”blue green on cap. Iron salts- slight gray/green on pores.

results.notes: Found in a park lawn that is contiguous with the area where I collected the specimens for my previous Observation (427020) – which have been identified by consensus as Pan. Cyanescens. These specimens are smaller and did not have reactive blue bruising from being handled, but did have faint but noticeable blue areas at the very base of the stipe which was visible prior to being collected. Iâ€™ve found other mushrooms that are macroscopically similar to these growing in residential lawns a few miles away. There always seem to be mushrooms that resemble Panaeolus Cinctulus or Foenisecii growing in the same lawns, but most of those do not exhibit the blueish coloring at the base – typically it has been specimens with dry-cracked golden-brown caps that have the bluish coloration at the base.
